awd_titl_txt: Model Reduction of High Dimensional Hidden Markov Models and Markov Decision Processes
awd_abstract_narration:
Intellectual Merit: We currently live in an era where data is a major currency promising a transformative change to our society. Consequently, there has been a surge in the use of machine learning (ML) algorithms on high dimensional data producing unstructured stochastic models. Such models tend to be of very high dimensions limiting their utility in various applications involving optimization or decision systems. This proposal focuses on developing a foundational theory for model reduction applied to classes of stochastic models, in particular, Hidden Markov Models (HMMs); these are stochastic models that are described by underlying finite dimensional state space. 

Broader Impact: Ultimately, a model reduction theory will impact many fundamental aspects related to complex stochastic models including simulation, prediction, coding, robust learning, decision design and reinforcement learning. This research will develop new insights to address similar questions for other stochastic models including jump linear systems, and graphical models with latent variables and will have a direct impact on problems related to artificial intelligence and reinforcement learning. The latter is emerging as a popular approach for many decision-systems applications involving social behavior-- where simple mechanistic models do not exist. Examples of such problems are critical infrastructures and smart services where high dimensional unstructured data is available in real time. Models emerging in such approaches tend to have very high dimensions. 

A foundational theory for model reduction will affect the way we learn and utilize complex stochastic models. As a result, this development will enter our courses at MIT in a fashion similar to how model reduction theory impacted courses in linear system theory. The development should affect classes in stochastic models, machine learning, and statistical learning theory, reinforcement learning, and AI.  We also intend to incorporate the connection between model reduction and statistical learning in our new MIT micromasters in statistics and data science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our investigation explored the complex interplay between learning systems from finite data and model approximation within high-dimensional systems. These systems present distinctive challenges: firstly, their structure is unknown, creating a lack of prior knowledge for parameterized model approximation. Secondly, there's uncertainty about the necessary amount of data for efficient system learning. Thirdly, in the realm of decisions and interventions, estimating the causal effect of introducing an input on the measured output is not straightforward.

Our methodology revolves around evaluating whether a given dataset can produce an input-output model with a specified level of approximation.

 This challenge holds significant relevance in numerous real-world applications, especially those tied to complex systems. Instances of such issues encompass the control of infinite-dimensional systems governed by partial differential equations, the management of intricate distributed systems, and the analysis of data originating from diverse sources with distinct characteristics, such as the interweaving of trends and periodicity alongside stochastic signals.

 

Our research has produced significant insights across diverse high-dimensional systems, encompassing categories such as high-dimensional linear systems, stochastically switched linear systems, and hidden Markov models. These findings forge a direct link between model approximation theory and the learning process from data. Specifically, in the realm of linear systems and stochastically switched linear systems, we leverage the established theory of Hankel model reduction. We construct an empirical Hankel matrix, allowing us to estimate the optimal model order that the current data can effectively learn. In the context of hidden Markov models, we employ tensor decomposition techniques to derive a low-dimensional approximation from the available data. In each of these instances, we present asymptotic convergence results and establish rates of convergence.

Within the realm of time-series analysis, our research focuses on a data-driven methodology aimed at extracting and learning a deterministic trend from an unknown stochastic component. This technique involves constructing an empirical Hankel matrix and leveraging its low-dimensional structure to accurately estimate and predict outcomes from the dataset.

 The imputation of an input/output response from a given set of sparse input/output data is crucial in causal learning. This challenge is prevalent across various applications, including drug discovery, recommendation engines, and reinforcement learning from batch data. Our approach combines matrix completion techniques with synthetic control methods to deduce causal relations between inputs and outputs. Addressing personalized treatment effects within this causal framework, our work provides robust guarantees in these fields.

 The implications of our work extend directly to the control of complex dynamical systems, with a particular focus on applications prompted by the challenges posed by Covid-19. Notably, our findings were instrumental in demonstrating how HVAC systems could be controlled to trap viruses in enclosed spaces, thereby offering a profound impact on mitigating the spread of infectious diseases. The control strategies were derived utilizing reinforcement learning techniques taking advantage of our earlier work on learning Hidden Markov processes from data as well as algorithmic solutions for semi-Markov processes.

This research has played a pivotal role in supporting the academic endeavors of several PhD students, including female students, contributing to their scholarly development and final employment. Furthermore, it has fostered collaborations with faculty across multiple institutions, emphasizing the interdisciplinary nature of our work and its broader impact on the scientific community. Finally, the applications focused on timely issues concerning the spread of infectious diseases.
